abstract.text: A database partition that contains related records.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Zones are an important part of how you organize your data. The public and private databases each have a single default zone. In the private database, you can use

objects to create additional custom zones as necessary. Use custom zones to arrange and encapsulate groups of related records in the private database. Custom zones support other capabilities too, such as the ability to write multiple records as a single atomic transaction.

Treat each custom zone as a single unit of data that is separate from every other zone in the database. Inside the zone, you add records as you would anywhere else. You can also create links between the records inside a zone by using the
class doesn’t support cross-zone linking, so each reference object must point to a record in the same zone as the current record.
class as-is and don’t subclass it.

Generally, you use instances of this class to create and manage custom zones. Although you can use this class to retrieve a database’s default zone, most operations act on records in the default zone by default, so you rarely need to specify it explicitly.
To create a custom zone, use
to create the zone object, and then save that zone to the user’s private database using a

object. You can’t save any records in the zone until you save it to the database. When creating records, explicitly specify the zone ID if you want the records to reside in a specific zone; otherwise, they save to the default zone. You can’t create custom zones in a public database.
object and saving it to the database, you don’t interact with the object much. Instead, most interactions occur with its corresponding
object, which you use to refer to the zone when creating records.

abstract.text: Store structured app and user data in iCloud containers that all users of your app can share.
An external file that belongs to a record.
An operation that modifies one or more record zones.
A collection of key-value pairs that store your app’s data.
A relationship between two records in a record zone.
A database partition that contains related records.
The capabilities that a record zone supports.
An object that uniquely identifies a record zone in a database.
The capabilities that the zone supports.
Returns the default record zone.
Creates a record zone object with the specified zone ID.
Creates a record zone object with the specified zone name.
A reference to the record zone’s share record.
The unique ID of the zone.
The default record zone’s name.
Create a schema to store your app’s objects as records in iCloud using CloudKit.

abstract.text: Define and update your schema with the CloudKit Schema Language.

abstract.text: Inspect and modify the schema and data for your app’s iCloud container.

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
